posts._title: Robert Frank – Harry Smith at the Breslin Hotel (2018)
posts.title: Harry Smith at the Breslin Hotel
posts.excerpt: In 1984, upon learning that his friend Harry Smith was being evicted from the Breslin Hotel, Allen Ginsberg encouraged Robert Frank to use his new video camera to document the move. Over a one-week period, Smith shows Frank examples of his collection of art, books, indigenous recordings and films.

posts.title: Gens du lac
posts.excerpt: It is the discovery of a document recognising the services rendered by two fishermen from Lake Geneva during the Occupation that triggered the investigation undertaken by Swiss author Janine Massard in her novel Gens du lac, published in 2013. Jean-Marie Straub retraces the itinerary of the son, Paulus – just as he and Danièle Huillet …

posts._title: Pierre Chenal –  La foire aux chimères aka Carnival of Illusions (1946)
posts.title: La foire aux chimères
posts.excerpt: A word from an expert on the area: dbmonteil of the IMDb: “La Foire aux chimères” is a jewel, a sparkling diamond. It would deserve one hundred comments, and that would not be enough. Pierre Chenal was a film noir director who made moderately successful movies before the war: “L’Alibi” which featured von Stroheim too …

posts.excerpt: From the BFI website: Television documentary featuring interviews with Japanese soldiers after the Second World War. posts._title: Louis King – Green Grass of Wyoming (1948)
posts.title: Green Grass of Wyoming
posts.excerpt: In this sequel to MY FRIEND FLICKA and THUNDERHEAD, young Ken McLaughlin buys a trotting horse named Crown Jewel, intending to train and race her. However, Thunderhead, the stallion he released to the wild, returns and steals Jewel to add to his herd. Ken gets Jewel back and also succeeds in bringing Thunderhead home before …

posts.title: The Century of the Self
posts.excerpt: The Century of The Self 4 Part series on how psychoanalitic theory was used by advertisers and governments in an attempt to control the public. 01 Happiness Machines: Edward Bernays and the invention of public relations and modern advertising 02 The Engineering of Consent: How the US Government turned to psychoanalytic principles after WWII as …

posts.title: La soirée
posts.excerpt: Unfinished film by Jean Eustache (1961, or ’63), with Jean-André Fieschi, Chantal Simon, Paul Vecchiali and André S. Labarthe. 7 minutes – No sound Quote: Premier film de Jean Eustache, librement inspiré d’une nouvelle de Maupassant, inachevé et sans bande son. Ce film retrouvé il y a une dizaine d’années fait l’objet d’une projection inédite. …

posts.title: Collected HD Works (1966-1983)
posts.excerpt: Anne Rees-Mogg was born in 1924 and died in 1984. She studied at Bristol Art School and Central School of Arts and Crafts before becoming an inspiring and dedicated teacher herself at the Regent Street Polytechnic from 1951 and Chelsea School of Art from 1964 to 1984. She was a committed advocate of artist’s filmmaking …

posts._title: Katsu Kanai – Ôkoku aka The Kingdom (1973)
posts.title: Ôkoku
posts.excerpt: KatsuKanai wrote: My first film, The Deserted Archipelago, emerged out of the intersections between my own experiences and fantasies and Japan’s postwar history, and, as such, I might call it the “Human Chapter” of my trilogy. In contrast, Good-bye pursues the mystery of my distant DNA. Since it moves from blood to land, I might …
